title: ADAPTIVE INDOMITABLE UKRAINE and the Unmentioned Dragon in the Room ... China
description: Krasnov, as he is usually wont to do, likes to suck up all the attention and oxygen out of any hot issue du jour in order to place himself front and center in the media … daily! It’s incessant and unending. And it is getting increasingly worse. Were it...
content:
Krasnov, as he is usually wont to do, likes to suck up all the attention and oxygen out of any hot issue du jour in order to place himself front and center in the media … daily! It’s incessant and unending. And it is getting increasingly worse. Were it to actually lead to meaningful policy and constructive outcomes, it might perhaps be worthwhile and even bearable. But it is almost as if it has become noise for noise’s sake … with nary anything meaningful resulting from it. The matter of finding a workable ceasefire and eventual cessation of hostilities in the Russo-Ukrainian war has unfortunately and sadly become the latest platform for such unavailing noise-making by Krasnov … to the needless suffering of the people of Ukraine and to the detriment of America’s global standing.

The Ukrainians and the Europeans must by now be suffering from a Krasnovian whiplash. He seemingly pinballs from one policy polarity to the other by the day, if not by the hour. All that big production leading to the horrendously ill-conceived Alaska summit with Putin in which he seemed to accede to all of Putin’s wishes and threw Ukraine under the bus by publicly delivering Putin’s ransom note with a loud warning ... “Ukraine Must Accept It” seems like eons ago. But it was just last week.

This week, after President Zelenskyy and his amazingly diverse and cohesive European support rolled into the White House, Krasnov is now singing a different tune… that Russia is the aggressor and that America is considering the possibility of declaring the air space of Ukraine as a “No Fly Zone” in support of the ground swell of global offers to provide Ukraine with real enforceable “Security Guarantees” (whatever that means). To discerning ears, that really amounts to simply a lot of meaningless grand standing hooey … empty and vacuous in its hurried utterance and lack of any cogent policy gravitas. It came across as another effort by Krasnov to get ahead of and simply insert himself front and center of the growing international “coalition of the willing” movement.

One can only wonder if either he or the White House has truly worked out and mapped out what a real “No Fly Zone” would mean and the resultant obligations which will entail upon the government of the United States now and into the foreseeable future. We are now in the throes of painfully dis-orienting policy-making actuated by the idiosyncrasies and vacillating personal whims of an uncurious mind with all the unhappy attributes of the Dunning–Kruger effect. Unfortunately, Zelenskyy and Europe, for now have to continue expending an inordinate amount of time and effort to manage this situation … owing to the unique position the U.S. still occupies as primus inter pares of the the Atlantic Alliance and NATO/OTAN.

Putin, on the other hand, knows this personality type all too well. He has shown nothing but what appears to be amused disdain and lack of seriousness with any of the effete utterances and threats made against Russia since Krasnov was again inaugurated into the U.S. Presidency in January 2025. He has been playing Krasnov like the proverbial fiddle … with zero consequences to himself or Russia to date. Putin can afford to be comfortable in his disdain. Why? Because in spite of all the incessant daily gyrations and noise from the White House, the words that really matter to Russia’s current situation come from another source … one which keeps a careful and studied near aloofness from the daily back and forth except for the occasional expression of high-minded desire to see a peaceful end to the Russo-Ukrainian war … The People's Republic of China. For Putin, at this point in time, that is what really matters because in a rare moment of official candor, the Chinese government told the world :

And increasingly evidence from intelligence sources as well as the battlefield leave no doubt that China is serious about what its Foreign Minister has said … extensive evidence of Chinese equipment, technology and even nationals fighting for the Russians keeps turning up. China also continues to provide both economic and political support for Russia, enabling Moscow to continue the war, however ineffectively. China is a vital strategic partner of Russia's and, as the dominant and larger partner, holds influence over Moscow's decision-making. It is also quite reasonable to assume that North Korea, another client state of China would not be as openly involved, including thousands of soldiers, on Russia’s side if China did not support Pyongyang’s growing involvement:

Thus, even if Putin disdains the pronouncements of the U.S. and Europe, it has to pay attention to what China thinks … because China, at bottom, is a trading nation and whilst its burgeoning economic power accrues much global power and influence, it cannot afford to cut off the hand that feeds it, as it were … trade with the United States and the West as a whole. Krasnov makes daily noises about tariffs and a militaristic pivot towards curtailing Chinese power in Southeast Asia. Which again elicits relatively careful studied and calibrated push backs from Beijing.

In antiquity, Athens and Sparta kept rubbing against each other in what is known as the “Thucydides' Trap”, a term popularized by American political scientist Graham T. Allison, which describes the perceived tendency towards war when an emerging power[China] threatens to displace an existing great power[United States] as a regional or international hegemon. In the final analysis, one would hope that unlike Athens and Sparta, China and the West, inter-dependent as they are, will do what is necessary to obviate the likes of the catastrophic Peloponnesian War. One fervently hopes that China will find a way to pull Putin and Russia from their hurtling dash to self-destruction and the needless convulsions and dislocations of a wider war.

So the reported upcoming meeting in Beijing of presidents Putin and Xi during China’s commemoration of the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II in Asia, could perhaps become a pivotal date in history. Surely, in the wake of the Krasnov-Putin Alaska Summit and the galvanizing global “Coalition of the Willing” effort, China will have something to say to Putin about his increasingly faltering war effort against Ukraine. Krasnov this week started pushing for a face-to-face meeting between Putin and Zelenskyy. But would it happen? Would China allow Putin to participate even if he was willing to? After all Zelenskyy today clapped back and refused China becoming one of the “security guarantors”?:

It is quite understandable that President Zelenskyy feels this way about China. But regardless of Zelenskyy’s unhappiness with China, it is increasingly evident that the end of this horrible war, absent a total catastrophic defeat of one side or total exhaustion of both sides, will come down to a negotiated agreement between the West(led unfortunately by Krasnov) and China’s Xi, the modern day Athens and Sparta, as it were:

For the sake of the good brave people of ADAPTIVE INDOMITABLE UKRAINE and their bright prosperous future, I believe that no matter how hurt President Zelenskyy is by how China has behaved in this war, he should bring to the China-Ukraine’s relationship the same spirit of studied aplomb and careful curation with which he has managed the unctuous, self-dealing Krasnov. No matter what any one says, the giant unmentioned dragon in the negotiating room, China, can not long be ignored. Great powers do what great powers do. President Zelenskyy MUST keep his eyes on the ultimate prize … a free, democratic, prosperous and fully European Ukraine.

The author points out that Russia is the aggressor and that America is considering declaring Ukraine's air space as a “No Fly Zone” in support of global offers to provide Ukraine with real enforceable “Security Guarantees” (whatever that means). This move is seen as another attempt by Krasnov to get ahead of and center of the growing international “coalition of the willing” movement. Putin, however, has shown no serious interest in this issue, with no consequences to either Russia or the United States. The article concludes that China continues to provide economic and political support for Russia, while the U.S. remains primus inter pares of the the Atlantic Alliance and NATO/OTAN.

China Will Not Allow Russia to Be Defeated in Its War in Ukraine, Chinese Foreign Minister Says
During a closed-door, four-hour meeting in Brussels, Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi told EU foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas that Beijing cannot accept a Russian defeat in its war against Ukraine.
According to South China Morning Post on July 4, which cited multiple sources familiar with the closed-door meeting, Wang expressed serious concern that a Russian defeat would shift the full focus of US strategic pressure onto China.
The remarks came during a tense four-hour meeting in Brussels — Kallas’s first major diplomatic engagement since assuming her new post as the EU’s top diplomat. Despite the frank tone, Wang denied any financial or military backing for Moscow.
This statement essentially confirms what many in Brussels already believe to be China’s true position, despite Beijing’s official stance that it is “not a party to the war.”
According to the sources, Wang argued that a Russian loss would be strategically dangerous for China, as it could lead to the United States shifting its full attention to countering Beijing.
The conversation, described as both tense and intense, marked Kaja Kallas’s first major diplomatic engagement in her new role. Throughout the four-hour meeting, Wang Yi firmly rejected accusations that China is providing military or financial support to Moscow. He also repeatedly interrupted the discussion to deliver “history lectures”
Earlier, it was reported that Russia is reportedly seeking to expand transport infrastructure in occupied Crimea with the help of Chinese companies, according to Ukraine’s Foreign Intelligence Service.

Putin–Zelenskyy meeting? Not without China in picture
A Putin–Zelenskyy meeting is virtually impossible before a Putin–Xi meeting takes place
Despite Trump’s blitz attempt to arrange such talks before Putin’s visit to China, the Kremlin is doing everything it can to stall for time.
De facto, Russia is now experiencing the lowest level of sovereignty since Putin came to power. He is going to Xi with a request for permission to continue his so-called “special military operation.”
After Alaska, Moscow officially proposed that China become a guarantor of the deal. In plain terms, this means Putin wants to present himself as a conditional mediator between Beijing and Washington. In reality, however, all he can offer are joint projects in the Northern Sea Route and Arctic development.
Putin’s actions show that he no longer pretends to be a third pole of global power. Instead, he acknowledges his need for dual protection so that one side does not crush him—particularly given Russia’s technological backwardness and inability to build a so-called sovereign economy.
For Ukraine, this is more of a positive than a negative signal. Neither China nor the U.S. wants to see Ukraine defeated, and neither side seeks a Russian victory. The problem is communication: Kyiv has virtually no channels with Beijing and speaks to Washington mostly through intermediaries. Increasingly, it looks as though the fate of this war will be decided in U.S.–China negotiations.
About the author: Vadym Denysenko, political scientist.

Exclusive | China tells EU it does not want to see Russia lose its war in Ukraine: sources
Wang Yi speaks of concern that US could shift whole focus in China’s direction in talks with top EU diplomat Beijing
Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi told the European Union’s top diplomat on Wednesday that Beijing did not want to see a Russian loss in Ukraine because it feared the United States would then shift its whole focus to Beijing, according to several people familiar with the exchange.
The comment, to the EU’s Kaja Kallas, would confirm what many in Brussels believe to be Beijing’s position but jar with China’s public utterances. The foreign ministry regularly says China is “not a party” to the war. Some EU officials involved were surprised by the frankness of Wang’s remarks.
However, Wang is said to have rejected the accusation that China was materially supporting Russia’s war effort, financially or militarily, insisting that if it was doing so, the conflict would have ended long ago.
During a marathon four-hour debate on a wide range of geopolitical and commercial grievances, Wang was said to have given Kallas – the former Estonian prime minister who only late last year took up her role as the bloc’s de facto foreign affairs chief – several “history lessons and lectures”.
Some EU officials felt he was giving her a lesson in realpolitik, part of which focused on Beijing’s belief that Washington would soon turn its full attention eastward, two officials said.

Only three countries in the world can boast the experience of waging modern warfare on a wide front using virtually all means. Among them are Ukraine, Russia, and North Korea, which is currently actively practicing its combat skills.
Points of attention
- North Korea is actively cooperating with Russia in the military sphere against Ukraine, providing significant ammunition supply and military equipment.
- The DPRK plans to send military engineering units to Russia for demining and restoration work, indicating a deepening military partnership.
- Budanov revealed the extent of North Korea's involvement in the Russian war against Ukraine, shedding light on the shared military activities between the two nations.
Budanov revealed the role of the DPRK in the Russian war against Ukraine
The head of the GUR of the Ministry of Defense of Ukraine, Kyrylo Budanov, said this in an interview with The Japan Times.
According to Budanov, Pyongyang intends to send military engineering units of about 6,000 people to Russia in the coming months. Their tasks include demining and restoration work in the Kursk region.
North Korea provides about 40% of the Russian army's needs for 122 and 152 mm ammunition. Production is carried out around the clock. In addition, Moscow received hundreds of artillery systems, multiple launch rocket systems and missiles from Pyongyang.

Zelenskyy on China as security guarantor: don't need those who didn't help when needed
China provided assistance to the Russian Federation by opening its drone market, and was also among the signatories of the Budapest Memorandum and did nothing when Crimea was occupied, so Ukraine does not need guarantors of its security who did not help it when it needed it, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has said.
"Why is China not in the guarantees? First, China did not help us stop this war from the beginning. Second, China helped Russia by opening the drone market. Third: the question here is not even about the military personnel who are present there. We are talking about the Budapest Memorandum," Zelenskyy said during a meeting with journalists on Wednesday.
"China was among these signatories, they did nothing when Crimea was occupied. That is why we do not need guarantors who do not help Ukraine and did not help Ukraine at a time when we really needed it after February 24," the head of the Ukrainian state added.
Zelenskyy stressed that Ukraine needs security guarantees only from those countries that are ready to help it.
